title.narrative: Landscapes 2021-2025

description.narrative: IDH Landscape approach aim to reconcile economic, environmental, and social needs to achieve the sustainable and equitable use of natural resources. IDH uses a Protection- reservation-Inclusion (PPI) approach in areas where the protection and restoration of natural ecosystems, in particular forests, is threatened by the expansion of agricultural production. The approach starts with convening government, private-sector companies producing in and/or sourcing from the landscape, and farmers and communities in a sub-national jurisdiction.

participating-org.narrative: The Royal Norwegian Ministry of Climate and Environment (KLD)

receiver-org.narrative: Public and private organizations and partners associated with IDH through signed contracts and agreements for the development and implementation of specific activities and projects in the program sectors that IDH operates in.

provider-org.narrative: The Royal Norwegian Ministry of Climate and Environment (KLD)

title.narrative: ISLA 2021 Annual Report
Improved Sector Governance

description.narrative: Change in sector agencies and sector institutions to manage the sector in a sustainable way at local and international levels. Improving sector governance for an enhanced enabling (policy) environment can be considered a pre-condition for changes in business practices to happen

title.narrative: Number of multi-stakeholder coalitions, committees, secretariats, initiatives, and platforms convened to sign and support a common vision, goals, or strategy on sustainable development or sourcing
Number of companies with MoUs, funding agreement or letter of assignment to invest, trade, and/or provide services

description.narrative: This indicators measures the unique number of companies with signed funding agreements, MoUs or Letters of Assignment can only be counted once for the year in which these companies joined a contractual partnership with IDH.

title.narrative: Improved Sector Governance

description.narrative: Change in sector agencies and sector institutions to manage the sector in a sustainable way at local and international levels. Improving sector governance for an enhanced enabling (policy) environment can be considered a pre-condition for changes in business practices to happen

title.narrative: Number of multi-stakeholder agreements signed as a result of IDH interventions
Number of new or improved policies or standards that are effectively enforced

description.narrative: The total number of new policies (including laws and regulations) launched by governments to enhance sustainable development related to IDH programs + the total number of improved policies (including laws and regulations) that were amended to enhance sustainable development related to IDH programs + total number of voluntary standards that were either created or amended to enhance sustainable business practices in IDH sectors.

title.narrative: Improved Business Practices

description.narrative: Change of behavior of business actors in the value chain, towards more sustainable business practices that contribute to a living wage for workers, living income for farmers, a better environment and gender equalit

title.narrative: Percentage of projects in IDH portfolio that are gender intentional

description.narrative: Counts the percentage of projects that are gender intentional. All IDH projects, with or without gender intentionality, are required to go through a self-assessment process using the gender tool during the pre-contracting phase.

title.narrative: Percentage of projects in IDH portfolio that are gender transformative

description.narrative: Counts the percentage of projects that are gender transformative. All IDH projects, with or without gender intentionality, are required to go through a self-assessment process using the gender tool during the pre-contracting phase.

title.narrative: Number of factories, cooperatives, SMEs, plantations, traders reached with technical assistance (non-financial assistance)

description.narrative: This indicator measures the unique number of Value Chain Actors with access to selected categories of technical assistance. Technical assistance refers to non-financial assistance provided by specialists. It can take the form of sharing information and expertise, instruction, skills training, transmission of working knowledge, and consulting services and may also involve the transfer of technical data or improved processes co-financed by IDH.

title.narrative: Number of diagnostic analysis finalized
Total amount program budget dedicated to climate change mitigation

description.narrative: Measurement of the commitments of program budget to climate change mitigation (in EUR.)

title.narrative: Total amount program budget dedicated to climate change adaptation

description.narrative: Measurement of the commitments of program budget to climate changeadaptation (in EUR.)

title.narrative: Improved Business Practices

description.narrative: Change of behavior of business actors in the value chain, towards more sustainable business practices that contribute to a living wage for workers, living income for farmers, a better environment and gender equalit

title.narrative: Offtake volumes of focus crops (metric tons)

description.narrative: Total volumes sourced by project partners from targeted SMEs, cooperatives, sector initiatives or farmers and meeting required (social and environmental) sustainability criteria.

title.narrative: Number of factories, cooperatives, SMEs, plantations, traders with improved access to financial services such as blended finance, equity, or commercial loans

description.narrative: Number of value chain actors that have access to blended finance, investment deals, commercial loans, lower interest rates, sharing of financing risks, access to funds beyond the borrowing limit, reduced loan tenor terms, or finance that links value chain partners to reduce price risk.

title.narrative: Private investments co-funding in the program
Number of targeted market actors that adopted or updated their sourcing, procurement policies or strategies to include sound social and environmental sustainability criteria and goals
Replication of investments and scaling by IDH partners

description.narrative: Models and sustainability solutions with proven business case in the implementation phase are taken to scale and replicated by the private sector companies and markets to truly make a difference.

title.narrative: Uptake rate of sustainable production by program partners or sectors

description.narrative: The percentage of the total volume (in metric tons) that is sourced sustainably by IDH program partners and/or the sector

title.narrative: Other sources of public, private or blended-finance investments/funding leveraged by the program
Proven business cases for field level projects

description.narrative: Sustainability impact at the level of producers, workers and producer communities, including their economic situation, their social well-being, and the sustainability of their natural resource base. For private sector companies to change their business practices it often is a pre-condition that the business case for new ways of organizing production and trade needs to be proven and disseminated.

title.narrative: Number of households or production facilities with improved water availability and access

description.narrative: The total on-site households or production facilities with improved access or availability of water from program or project intervention.

title.narrative: Adoption rate of sustainable manufacturing, production, and land-use management practices

description.narrative: Adoption of sustainable practice might include: sustainable manufacturing practices, good agricultural practices, land management practices as a result of IDH intervention.

title.narrative: Number of licensed / certified farmers or farmers compliant to the quality or sustainability standards of offtakers

description.narrative: Number of farmers achieving certification status in a specific production or management practice.

title.narrative: Number of farmers with increased number of animal products (meat, dairy, wool, honey, etc.) produced on farm for sale or for consumption.

description.narrative: Number of farmers with increased animal products, such as meat, dairy, wool, honey, eggs, milk, etc. produced on farm for sale or consumption.

title.narrative: Area of cropland and other non-timber commodity production under sustainable (intensification) production and management practices

description.narrative: The total on-site, non-forested and non-wooded area in which sustainable agricultural production and land(use) management practices are applied and field-level sustainability projects co-developed and co-financed by IDH.

title.narrative: Number of farmers with offtake seasonal, annual or longer-term contracts signed per year

description.narrative: Number of farmers with seasonal, annual or longer term contracts signed per year with Cooperatives, SMEs or traders or informal agreements

title.narrative: Area of forest(ed) land under sustainable (agro) forest management or other improved conservation or protection practices

description.narrative: The total forested and wooded area in which sustainable forest management practices are applied under the scope of field-level sustainability projects co-developed and co-financed by IDH. This total includes on-site and off-site areas.

title.narrative: Number of farmers with increased number of crops (including those intercropped with focus crop) cultivated by the farmer

description.narrative: Number and type of crops grown by the household and cropped land.

title.narrative: Proven business cases for field level projects

description.narrative: Sustainability impact at the level of producers, workers and producer communities, including their economic situation, their social well-being, and the sustainability of their natural resource base. For private sector companies to change their business practices it often is a pre-condition that the business case for new ways of organizing production and trade needs to be proven and disseminated.

title.narrative: Area of soil under restoration and rehabilitation practices (on site)

description.narrative: The total on-site, productive area, including agricultural, cropland, agro-forestry and pastureland, under practices that are expected to improve soil quality by increasing the topsoil (0-30 cm of depth) organic carbon content.

title.narrative: Number of farming households with increased net income

description.narrative: Measurement of the number of farming households with increased net income due to IDH intervention, adjusted when possible, as per the consumer price index during the course of the intervention.

title.narrative: Greenhouse gas emissions reduced (tCO2eq)
Number of hectares of cropland covered by PPI governance
Greenhouse gas emissions sequestered (tCO2eq)
Number of hectares of forest/watersheds covered by PPI governance
Proven business cases for field level projects

description.narrative: Sustainability impact at the level of producers, workers and producer communities, including their economic situation, their social well-being, and the sustainability of their natural resource base. For private sector companies to change their business practices it often is a pre-condition that the business case for new ways of organizing production and trade needs to be proven and disseminated.

title.narrative: Number of farmers gained access to inputs and technology, including ICT

description.narrative: The unique number of farmers, who gained access to inputs, services or technology as a result of activities co-financed by IDH.

title.narrative: Number of agronomists extension workers and experts trained

description.narrative: The unique number of field facilitators such as agronomists, extension staff and experts trained to deliver further training to farmers, SMEs, factories, Cooperatives, traders.

title.narrative: Number of farmers and workers trained

description.narrative: The unique number of farmers and workers with access to trainings that are co-financed by IDH. This does not refer to the number of times in which a farmer/worker has been trained. If a person attended training twice, they may only be counted once.

title.narrative: Number of farmers who gained access to financial services

description.narrative: The unique number of farmers and workers who have gained access to finance as a result of activities co-financed by IDH.
